statement.p: A function f is said to be one-to-one if it never takes on the same value twice, or in notation, f(x_1) \neq f(x_2) when x_1\neq x_2.
A function is one-to-one if and only if no horizontal line intersects its graph more than once.

example.statement: Is f(x) = x^5 one-to-one? Why or why not?

solution.p: Yes: if x_1\neq x_2, then f(x_1) = (x_1)^5 and f(x_2) = (x_2)^5, which are distinct.

example.statement: Is f(x) = x^2 one-to-one? Why or why not?

solution.p: No: f(-1) = f(1) = 1, so two inputs produce the same output.

statement.p: Let f(x) = x^k, where k is an even number. Using the previous exercise, do you think this function is one-to-one? Why or why not?

solution.p: Any even power function (in fact, any even function) is not one-to-one, as f(-a) = f(a) for any a in the domain of f.

statement.p: Let f be a one-to-one function with domain A and range B. The inverse function is notated \inv{f}, with domain B and range A. The inverse function is defined by the equation \inv{f}(y) = x\iff f(x) = y for any y\in B.

assemblage.title: Notation Alert!
assemblage.p: \inv{f} is a special notation to indicate the function inverse; you should not confuse this with the notation for the multiplicative inverse (reciprocal), such as \inv{x}. That is,

ul.li: \inv{f}(x) denotes the inverse of a function
\inv{x} denotes the multiplicative inverse of a variable, i.e. \inv{x} = \dfrac{1}{x}

assemblage.title: Continuity of Inverses
assemblage.p: If f is a one-to-one continuous function defined on the interval I, then \inv{f} is also continuous on I.

statement.p: If a one-to-one function f is differentiable on the interval I, is it necessarily true that \inv{f} is also differentiable?

solution.p: No; if f(x) = x^3, then its inverse is \inv{f}(x) = x^{1/3}, which is not differentiable at x=0.

assemblage.title: Derivative of Inverses (at a Point)
assemblage.p: If f is a one-to-one, differentiable function at x = a with inverse function \inv{f} and f'(\inv{f}(a))\neq 0, then the inverse function is differentiable at a and (\inv{f})'(a) = \dfrac{1}{f'(\inv{f}(a))}
